name: Ozette Mudslide
detailed_description: A massive mudslide at Ozette, Washington, buries part of a Makah village. This event preserved six longhouses and thousands of artifacts, becoming one of the most significant archaeological sites in the Pacific Northwest.

name: Josephs Smith’s First Vision
detailed_description: Near Manchester, New York, Joseph Smith reports seeing God the Father and Jesus Christ in a grove of trees. This marks the beginning of the Restoration movement and forms the theological foundation of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. This location is now referred to as the sacred grove.

name: Angel Moroni Appears to Joseph Smith
detailed_description: Joseph Smith states that the angel Moroni visits him during the night and tells him of golden plates hidden in a nearby hill. Moroni also shares prophecies and spiritual instruction over the next several years.

name: Plates Received by Joseph Smith
detailed_description: Smith says he receives the golden plates from Moroni on the Hill Cumorah. These plates will become the source text for the Book of Mormon.

name: Book of Mormon Published
detailed_description: The Book of Mormon is published and goes on sale in Palmyra, New York. These were printed by E. B. Grandin.

name: LDS Church Organized
detailed_description: The Church is formally organized in Fayette, New York with six original members, under the name the Church of Christ. This date is now recognized as the founding of the The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

name: Move to Ohio Begins
detailed_description: Due to religious persecution and hostility the church moved east looking for greater religious freedom. Following revelations directing the Saints to gather in Ohio, Joseph Smith and other Church members begin relocating to Kirtland, Ohio.

name: Missouri Extermination Order against LDS
detailed_description:
Missouri Governor Lilburn Boggs issues Executive Order 44, declaring that Mormons must be treated as enemies and "exterminated or driven from the state." This order leads to widespread violence and the expulsion of Church members.

Source: https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/study/history/topics/extermination-order?lang=eng

name: Nauvoo Settled by LDS
detailed_description: Mormon pioneers begin settling in Nauvoo, Illinois, creating a thriving city. Nauvoo becomes a spiritual and political stronghold for the LDS.

name: Joseph Smith Killed
detailed_description: Joseph Smith and his brother Hyrum are murdered by a mob at Carthage Jail, Illinois. The event causes a leadership crisis and deepens the Saints’ desire for a place of safety.

name: Mormon Exodus Begins
detailed_description: Facing increasing hostility, Brigham Young leads the first group of LDS from Nauvoo to the Salt Lake Valley.

name: Pioneers Arrive in Salt Lake Valley
detailed_description: Brigham Young and the first pioneers arrive in the Salt Lake Valley, which becomes the center of the Church in the West. This date is now celebrated annually as Pioneer Day in Utah.

name: California Gold Rush Begins
detailed_description:
Gold is discovered at Sutter's Mill, marking the beginning California Gold Rush. In following years, the Yurok people face land seizures, massacres, and forced removals.

“By the end of the gold rush era at least 75% of the Yurok people died due to massacres and disease, while other tribes in California saw a 95% loss of life.”

Source: https://www.yuroktribe.org/gold-rush-in-yurok-country

name: Polygamy Publicly Announced
detailed_description: Church leaders officially disclose the practice of plural marriage at a special conference. Though practiced privately earlier, this is the first time it's publicly acknowledged.

name: Establishment of the Klamath River Reservation
detailed_description:
The U.S. government establishes the Klamath River Reservation by executive order to provide land for the Yurok and other tribes. In practice it limited Yurok sovereignty.

Source: https://www.nps.gov/parkhistory/online_books/redw/history8m.htm

name: Utah War Ends
detailed_description:
The Utah war was conflict between the federal government led by President James Buchanan and the LDS led by Bringham Young. He had been governor for 7 years and during that time the LDS had significant influence. David Roberts of the Smithsonian magazine described it as a theocracy. The event represented growing hostility to the LDS over variety of issues including governance, land ownership, plural marriage, and Indian relations. In exchange for peace, Young stepped down as governor.

“On June 19, the New York Herald summarized the non-engagement: "Killed, none; wounded, none; fooled, everybody."”

“Statehood for Utah followed in 1896.Their dreams of dominion over, the Mormons began to enter the American fold.”

Sources: https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/the-brink-of-war-48447228/

name: Treaty of Neah Bay Ratified
detailed_description:
The Makah sign the Treaty of Neah Bay with the U.S. government, ceding most of their territory. However, they explicitly retain the right to hunt whales and other marine mammals—a central part of Makah identity.

“During the negotiation of the Treaty of Neah Bay, a tribal leader declared, “I want the sea. That is my country.””

U.S. federal laws and international whaling bans, like those by the International Whaling Commission, prohibited Makah whale hunting. Intended for conservation, these policies restricted Makah treaty rights.

Source: https://goia.wa.gov/tribal-government/treaty-neah-bay-1855 https://iwc.int/management-and-conservation/whaling/aboriginal/usa/makah-tribe

name: The Indian Appropriations Act of 1871
detailed_description:
“The Indian Appropriations Act of 1871 declared that Indigenous people were no longer considered members of “sovereign nations” and that the US government could no longer establish treaties with them. “

Source: https://coloradoencyclopedia.org/article/indian-appropriations-act-1871#id-field-article-image

name: Chemawa Indian School opened
detailed_description:
The Forest Grove Indian Industrial Training School opens in Oregon. It is one of many such schools where Native American children were forced into boarding schools in an effort to ‘assimilate’ them into the dominant white society. Children were forbidden from speaking their languages, accelerating the decline of Yurok fluency and culture.

“It is now known as the Chemawa Indian School and remains the oldest operating school of its kind.”

Over time the school has changed significantly from its original purpose. They describe themselves as follows:

“Chemawa Indian School is over 125 years old, making it the oldest, continuously operated boarding school for Native American students in the United States. While its mission has changed over the years, its most important goal has always been educating Native American students and preparing them for success in the future. Recently, the school has embarked on a more rigorous mission to help students reach the highest goals and achieve the most they can in their life after high school. This is complemented by the help of the Indian Health Services clinic located right on campus, the AVID program, which seeks to help underserved students with access to higher-level classes and college entrance requirements, and the Chemawa Partnership Program with Willamette University, which brings enthusiastic college students to campus to interact with Chemawa students.”

Sources: https://cis.bie.edu/our-school/our-history https://www.opb.org/article/2025/02/25/chemawa-indian-school-opened-145-years-ago/

name: Immigration Convention of 1886
detailed_description:
The United States and Japan signed a treaty aimed at protecting Japanese laborers on Hawain sugar plantations. This agreement led to increased Japanese migration to Hawaii’s sugar plantations. Japanese laborers were replacements for Chinese workers, who were being excluded at the time.

“This accord redefined Japanese plantation workers as wards of the Hawaiian government and established planters as agents responsible for their welfare, thereby subjecting plantation practices to government oversight. Despite its initial promise, the convention's provisions for accountability were largely ineffective within a year. ”

Sources: https://www.ebsco.com/research-starters/history/immigration-convention-1886 https://www.congress.gov/bill/99th-congress/senate-bill/1200/text

name: Polygamy Officially Ended
detailed_description: Church President Wilford Woodruff issues the Manifesto, officially ending the practice of plural marriage in the Church. This declaration paves the way for Utah's eventual statehood. Polygamy was one of the major points of hostility between the LDS and general public.

name: Utah Gains Statehood
detailed_description: Utah becomes the 45th U.S. state after decades of political tension, mostly surrounding polygamy and federal authority over the Utah Territory.

name: The Philippine War begins
detailed_description:
After the Spanish-American War of 1898, Spain ceded the colony of the Philippines to the United States in the Treaty of Paris. Filipinos, led by Emilio Aguinaldo, fought for independence. Throughout the war, approximately 4,200 Americans, 20,000 Filipino combatants, and 200,000 Filipino civilians died.

Source: https://history.state.gov/milestones/1899-1913/war

name: Filipino laborers arrives in Hawaii
detailed_description:
The first group of Sakadas (Filipino laborers) arrives in Hawaii to work on sugar plantations. As U.S. nationals, they migrate freely but face exploitative labor practices, low wages, and racial segregation.

“Those American corporations sought low-cost laborers, and they recruited, some would say extracted, from the Philippines hundreds of thousands of Filipinx men called “sakadas” to work the fields. They were paid sometimes as little as 90 cents a day, much less than other migrant workers from Japan and Korea. ”

Source: https://news.berkeley.edu/2023/10/09/why-are-there-so-many-people-from-the-philippines-in-hawaii/

name: The Philippine War Ends
detailed_description:
The war was declared over by President Theodore Roosevelt, however, smaller conflicts occurred over the next few years.

“In 1907, the Philippines convened its first elected assembly, and in 1916, the Jones Act promised the nation eventual independence. The archipelago became an autonomous commonwealth in 1935, and the U.S. granted independence in 1946.”

Until 1946, the country's status as a US colony meant Philippine immigrants were a source of cheap labor in the West, even after the 1924 immigration act.

https://history.state.gov/milestones/1899-1913/war

name: California Alien Land Law
detailed_description:
Amid growing anti Japanese sentiment California passed a series of laws meant to prevent land ownership.

“... California passed the Alien Land Law of 1913 prohibiting aliens ineligible for citizenship from owning land, and adding a prohibition against aliens ineligible for citizenship from possessing long-term leases.”

Sources: https://calendar.eji.org/racial-injustice/may/3 https://encyclopedia.densho.org/Alien_land_laws/

name: The Immigration Act of 1924 (Johnson-Reed Act)
detailed_description:
This federal law ends all immigration from Asia, including Japan. It sets strict national origin quotas and explicitly bars Japanese immigrants. A previous 1917 act excluded Japaenese and Filipinos from the “barred zone” of countries from immigration limitiations.

Source: https://history.state.gov/milestones/1921-1936/immigration-act

name: The Immigration Act of 1924 (The Johnson-Reed Act)
detailed_description:
“The Immigration Act of 1924 limited the number of immigrants allowed entry into the United States through a national origins quota. The quota provided immigration visas to two percent of the total number of people of each nationality in the United States as of the 1890 national census. It completely excluded immigrants from Asia.”

The Philippines, as a US colony, became a source of cheap labor as its citizens were considered US nationals.

Source: https://history.state.gov/milestones/1921-1936/immigration-act

name: Watsonville Riots
detailed_description:
“The attacks against Filipinos grew into five days of violence from Jan. 19-23. It included throwing Filipinos off the Pajaro Bridge. Rioters also shot up a bunkhouse in Murphy's Crossing Labor Camp, where they killed 22-year-old Fermin Tobera as he slept.

The violence in Watsonville would spark riots in other California cities across the Bay Area and Central Valley.”

This period of violence was a motivation for congress to eventually pass the Tydings-McDuffie Act which greatly limited Filipino immigration.

Source: https://www.ksbw.com/article/aapi-heritage-remembering-the-watsonville-riots-of-1930/36482159

name: Tydings-McDuffie Act
detailed_description:
This act was signed by President Franklin D. Roosevelt. This provided Philippine independence on July 4, 1946 after a 10-year period.

“This change in status allowed Congress to impose an immigration quota of 50 persons per year, effectively ending Filipino immigration.”

Sources: https://immigrationhistory.org/item/tydings-mcduffie-act/ https://www.britannica.com/topic/Tydings-McDuffie-Act

name: Attack on Pearl Harbor
detailed_description:
Japan attacks the U.S. naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, directly resulting America into World War II. The attack intensifies anti-Japanese sentiments across the mainland U.S. This sets the stage for Japanese American incaceration.

Source: https://www.nationalww2museum.org/war/topics/pearl-harbor-december-7-1941

name: Executive Order 9066
detailed_description:
President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs Executive Order 9066, authorizing the forced removal “all persons deemed a threat to national security from the West Coast to ‘relocation centers’”. This resulted in incarceration of over 120,000 Japanese Americans, many were U.S. citizens.

“Nearly 70,000 of the evacuees were American citizens. The government made no charges against them, nor could they appeal their incarceration. All lost personal liberties; most lost homes and property as well.”

Source: https://www.archives.gov/milestone-documents/executive-order-9066

name: Closure of the Last Incarceration Camp
detailed_description:
The Tule Lake Segregation Center, the last incarceration site, officially closes. By this time, most Japanese Americans have been released

“ … total property loss is estimated at $1.3 billion, and net income loss at $2.7 billion (calculated in 1983 dollars based on a congressional commission investigation)… In 1988, Public Law 100-383 acknowledged the injustice of the incarceration, apologized for it, and provided partial restitution – a $20,000 cash payment to each person who was incarcerated.”

Source: https://www.nps.gov/places/tule-lake.htm https://eacc.janm.org/camp/tule-lake/ https://www.archives.gov/milestone-documents/executive-order-9066

name: Tydings-McDuffie Act
detailed_description:
The Philippines officially becomes an independent republic after the 10 year period set up in the Tydings-McDuffie Act. On the same day, the Luce-Celler Act is enacted, allowing 100 Filipinos to immigrate annually and offering a path to naturalization for Filipinos already in the U.S.

Source: https://www.saada.org/news/20140702-3609

name: The Delano Grape Strike Begins
detailed_description:
Filipino farmworkers, led by Larry Itliong, walk off vineyards in Delano, California. They demand fair pay and decent working conditions.

Source: https://www.pbssocal.org/shows/kvie-viewfinder/episodes/kvie-viewfinder-delano-manongs

name: Cesar Chavez and NFWA Join the Strike
detailed_description:
Cesar Chavez and the NFWA vote to support the Filipino-led movement. The two groups merge into what becomes the United Farm Workers (UFW). This was a pivotal moment in American labor history.

Source: https://www.pbssocal.org/shows/kvie-viewfinder/episodes/kvie-viewfinder-delano-manongs

name: Victory in the Delano Grape Strike
detailed_description:
After five years, grape growers sign contracts with the UFW. Workers gain better pay, benefits, and protections. But the contributions of Filipinos like Itliong are often overshadowed by Chavez's media spotlight.

Source: https://www.pbssocal.org/shows/kvie-viewfinder/episodes/kvie-viewfinder-delano-manongs

name: Ozette Village Discovery
detailed_description:
A storm exposed the long-buried Ozette village. Over the next two decades, Makah members and archaeologists excavated more than 55,000 artifacts, preserving an unique opportunity to examine the history of the Makah.

Source: https://makahmuseum.com/about/ozette-archaeological-site/

name: Larry Itliong Resigns from UFW
detailed_description:
Due to the marginalization of Filipino members in the UFW, Itliong resigns from the organization. He continues advocating for Filipino elder care and community organizing until his death in 1977.

Source: https://www.pbssocal.org/shows/kvie-viewfinder/episodes/kvie-viewfinder-delano-manongs

name: Agbayani Village is dedicated
detailed_description:
Agbayani Village, a retirement home in Delano for aging Filipino farmworkers built by the UFW. Completed in 1977, the village stands as a tribute to their labor and sacrifice in the U.S. agricultural industry.

“The first affordable housing complex was named after Paolo Agbayani, a Filipino farm worker and United Farm Workers member who died of a heart attack on the picket line during the Delano Grape Strike in 1967.”

Source: https://chavezfoundation.org/2024/06/03/agbayani-village-a-legacy-of-unity-and-courage-in-delano

name: Makah Cultural and Research Center Opens
detailed_description:
The Makah Museum is established in Neah Bay to house the Ozette collection. It remains a cultural cornerstone for the Makah Nation.

Source https://makahmuseum.com/

name: Makah Resume Whale Hunt
detailed_description:
“The Tribe resumed exercising its treaty right to hunt gray whales in the late 1990s after the Eastern North Pacific stock had recovered from commercial exploitation and landed its first whale in seventy years in 1999. Consistent with international and domestic law, the Tribe’s hunt is for subsistence and cultural purposes only and prohibits the commercial sale of edible whale products.”

Due to public backlash and the efforts of NGOs and other organization the Makah were prevented from completing additional hunts.

Source: https://iwc.int/management-and-conservation/whaling/aboriginal/usa/makah-tribe

name: Archie Thompson dies
detailed_description:
Archie Thompson was the last living native speaker of the Yurok language. Today Yurok is taught in public schools in the Klamath River region of Northern California.

The Yurok Language Project worked with Archie Thompson and other elders to record the Yurok language. They helped publish dictionaries for use by educators.

The Yurok Tribe Language Program continued their work and conducted their first teacher training in July 2007. Currently the Yurok language is taught in over five high schools, encouraging students to interact and connect with the local culture. For many students this represents an opportunity to develop greater connection with the region and their history.

Sources: https://ictnews.org/archive/how-archie-thompson-saved-the-yurok-language/ https://publications.csba.org/california-school-news/november-2022/californias-yurok-tribe-is-revitalizing-language-in-and-out-of-the-classroom/

name: Delano Manongs Documentary Premieres
detailed_description:
Delano Manongs: Forgotten Heroes of the United Farm Workers premieres. The film spotlights Larry Itliong and other Filipino leaders in the farmworker movement. The film is to remind and educate about the Filipino contributions in labor history.

Sources: https://www.delanomanongs.com/ https://itvs.org/films/delano-manongs/

name: California Declares Larry Itliong Day
detailed_description:
California officially recognizes October 25—Larry Itliong’s birthday—as Larry Itliong Day, honoring his role in labor organizing and Filipino American civil rights. It’s a key win for historical recognition and ethnic pride.

Source: https://www.nps.gov/people/larry-itliong.htm

name: Makah Tribe to Resume Gray Whale Hunt
detailed_description:
The NOAA approved the the waiver after over 20 years of effort of the Makah tribe. The waiver attempts to balance protection of the whales with the important cultural significance of whaling to the Makah.

“All of the Tribe’s efforts to increase tolerance and understanding of its whale hunt, a hunt which is a spiritual manifestation of the connection between Makahs and their Creator and a realization of the right their ancestors secured through the Treaty of Neah Bay, have not prevented continued opposition to Makah whaling. This opposition to the hunt increasingly reflects a narrow, ideological interest, as many mainstream environmental NGOs have expressed support for the Tribe’s proposed hunt and exercise of its treaty-protected right to hunt whales. Thus, despite the substantial adverse effects on the Tribe from the hiatus in whaling caused by the depletion of gray whales by non-Native whalers, despite the fact that the Tribe delayed exercising its Treaty right until the ENP gray whale population returned to healthy numbers, despite the Tribe’s efforts to limit the scope of its hunt and comply with all IWC humane kill requirements, despite the Tribe’s diligent efforts to comply with the extraordinarily complex and time-consuming domestic management process, despite the Tribe’s compliance with additional restrictions resulting from that process, and despite the Tribe’s contributions to the body of scientific knowledge about gray whales, opponents of Makah whaling will likely ensure that the recently issued waiver and any subsequent decisions by NOAA to authorize a Makah hunt – no matter how limited – will be reviewed by United States federal courts. ”

Source: https://iwc.int/management-and-conservation/whaling/aboriginal/usa/makah-tribe

name: Yurok Tribe land returned
detailed_description:
Approximately 72 square miles were returned to the Yurok, in one of the largest of such deals in state history.

“The drainage is not just important to the natural resource, but it’s a place of high prayer for us.”

On the land the Yurok tribe focuses on sustainable logging and forest restoration. Along with their previously held land this is significant source of revenue for the Yurok as the it allows for the collection of Carbon credits for the important work the local ecosystems do in acting as a carbon sink. This serves as major source of discretionary funding for the Yurok.
